article:
In nuclear sciences and technologies, "activity" is the SI quantity related to
the phenomenon of natural and artificial radioactivity. The SI unit of
"activity" is becquerel, Bq, while that of "specific activity" is Bq/kg. The old
unit of "activity" was curie, Ci, while that of "specific activity" was Ci/g.
For its use in radiochemistry, see radioactivity.

One can use the experimentally measured 'specific activity' to calculate the half-
life of an element.

Starting from the definition of the half-life ('T 1/2 ') - with,
'N 0', atoms of an element, the number of atoms, 'N', remaining after
time, 't', is giving by:

: N=N_0\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{t \over T_{1/2} }

Take the natural log of both sides:

: \ln(N)=\ln(N_0)+\left(\frac{t}{T_{1/2}
:}\right)\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)

Take the derivative with respect to time, t:

: \frac{1}{N}\frac{dN}{dt}=\frac{\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)}{T_{1/-
:2} }

Multiply both sides by N:

: \frac{dN}{dt}=\frac{N\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)}{T_{1/2} }

Which is:

: \frac{dN}{dt}=\frac{-0.693\,N}{T_{1/2} }

dN/dt represents the decay rate of atoms. The negative sign shows that the rate
is negative, so the number of atoms is decreasing with time as you would expect.
Rearranging terms:

: T_{1/2}=\frac{-0.693\,N}{\frac{dN}{dt} }

'Example: determine the half-life of Rb-87'

Suppose you have a gram of rubidium-87 and with your Geiger counter, you get a
count rate which, after taking solid angle effects into account, is consistent
with a decay rate of 3200 decays per second; this would correspond to a
'specific activity of 3.2Ã10 6 Bq/kg'. The atomic weight is of the
rubidium is 87, so one gram is one 87th of a mole, or N=6.9Ã10 21
atoms. Plugging in the numbers:

: T_{1/2}=\frac{-0.693(6.9\times 10^{21})}{-3200\text{ sec}^{-1}
:}=1.5\times 10^{18}\text{ sec or 47 million years!}
